awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Collaborative Research: Designing a Programming Language for Patient-Oriented Prescriptions
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: SHF: Small: Collaborative Research: Designing a Programming Language for Patient-Oriented Prescriptions

Medical errors in hospitals cause 2 to 4 million patient injuries and 440,000 deaths in US hospitals annually; this amounts to one-sixth of annual US deaths. Despite the expenditure of billions of dollars, computerization has failed to solve this problem. This failure can be attributed to a pervasive misunderstanding of the nature of healthcare prescriptions. This project conceptualizes prescriptions as programs and uses this essential insight to make significant progress in reducing medical error. The intellectual merits of this project include new insights regarding the building and maintenance of domain-specific languages and new general methods for developing high-reliability software that facilitates collaboration between machines and humans. The project's broader significance and importance is the development of powerful tools for improving the efficacy and safety of healthcare in the US. The main upshots are to give clinicians a public-domain, open-source framework for designing, creating, debugging, and tackling a broad array of prescriptions for managing medical problems; give researchers tools for acquiring data about the effect of healthcare interventions; and eventually to provide a simple, inexpensive means for conducting cohort studies, statistical process control trials, and randomized controlled trials.

The project is designing and building the Patient-Oriented Prescription Programming Language (POP-PL) with the goal of using software engineering techniques to implement and maintain highly reliable electronic prescriptions. The research leads to new approaches to event-based programming, new type systems and analyses to find medical error, new debugging and iterative refinement techniques to improve reliability of prescriptions and programs generally, and new ways to conceptualize staged programming based on the staging that already occurs in medical care.

por.por_cntn:
The work in this proposal is founded on the insight is that patient safety critically depends on accurate performance of medical prescriptions. Here, "prescription" refers to the entire set of instructions that govern the plan of healthcare for an individual patient; these instructions may specify tasks to be performed by a patient, caregiver, or clinician. These tasks may require precise sequencing, or be complexly contingent on the patient's lab results, or rely on communication among team members, or compete with one another for resources, or require decisions or actions of clinicians.


While it is possible for a physician to treat patients without consulting relevant research articles, practice guidelines, expert opinions, or textbooks, a physician cannot order drug therapy without a prescription. That is, the prescription is on the critical path between intent and practice. We take advantage of this insight to bring computers to bear on the problem of medical error. Through this work, we explore the position that a prescription is a program. Although computers are widely deployed in healthcare, they lack effective prescription management software, such as would be useful for handling the continuously changing, low-level vigilance tasks common in a clinical setting. We take advantage of the prevalence of computers to empower clinicans by giving them more control over their prescriptions and the attendant vigilance tasks -- the same control that a programmer has over a computer.


We believe the root cause of many fatal medication errors to be analogous to the root causes in bugs in computer programs. Accordingly, our goal is to design and build a new programming language that lets us express prescriptions directly as programs. Our hope is that we will then be able to bring programming languages and software engineering knowledge directly to bear on the problem of medical error.


This project focused on the design of the programming language. We designed, built, and evaluated a programming language and reported on it (Florence et al, 2018 TOPLAS). That work shows that prescriptions can be described as programs and that clinicians can understand and modify those prescriptions. We also discovered that the synchronous-reactive programming model is better suited to expressing the complex control flows in prescriptions and our most recent work is exploring that model and how it better expressed prescriptions.

Modified by: Robert Findler
